tweets.text: @Peter19195280 @frances_cutler Good morning Sir James Bevan @JamesBevanEA As Chief Executive of the Environment Agency would you like to comment on whether the @EnvAgency has a statutory duty and moral obligation to tell the truth to the public? How can you justify NDAs?

@bradfordmdc @EnvAgencyYNE @Bradford_TandA @WYFRS @EnvAgency Thank you. Its clear from the T&A article I sent a link to previously that CBMDC did have an application for the site to be used as a tyre disposal site and were due to consider it on 8 May 2017. Perhaps the CBMDC planning department could let us know the outcome?

We are delighted to have added two new talks to PiXL Stretch from the @EnvAgency on microplastic pollution.

At a time when this issue has never been more important to understand, we hope you might like to share these with students. 

Launch PiXL Stretch: https://t.co/B4XD9ImZiS https://t.co/SqzF3NOkAs

@CRTContactUs the river aire in armley beneath viaduct road smells awful at the moment, like human waste and chemicals. Especially where the drains exit from the industrial units& building works going on.
Is the crt responsible for this stretch of the river?

@Peter19195280 @frances_cutler The answer is that we need to get legal certainty about whether this is a matter on which the EA has a statutory duty to inform the public. (It seems to me that it obviously should be but one needs to quote chapter and verse. Where would we find that?)

@Castafi0re @Whatcroft @JohnSensible @HuwMerriman @frances_cutler It certainly should be illegal for a regulator to sign an NDA on anything. The @EnvAgency are there to protect our resources, not to protect a polluter and destroyer of the environment
